content.question: For a car driven <math alttext="100" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> kilometers at a constant speed, the amount of fuel used as a function of the speed is modeled by a differentiable function <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Fuel is measured in liters, and speed is measured in kilometers per hour (<math alttext="kilometers per hour" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>km/hr</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>). In this context, which of the following is a correct interpretation of the statement <math alttext="F prime of 50, is greater than F prime of 80" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>50</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>></mo><msup><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>80</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math> ?

choices.label: Driving at <math alttext="50 kilometers per hour" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext>km/hr</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> uses more fuel than driving at <math alttext="80 kilometers per hour" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>80</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext>km/hr</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The rate at which <math alttext="50" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> liters of fuel is used is greater than the rate at which <math alttext="80" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>80</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> liters of fuel is used.

The rate of change of the speed is greater when driving at <math alttext="50 kilometers per hour" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext>km/hr</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> than when driving at <math alttext="80 kilometers per hour" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>80</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext>km/hr</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The rate of change of liters of fuel used with respect to the speed is greater when driving at <math alttext="50 kilometers per hour" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext>km/hr</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> than when driving at <math alttext="80 kilometers per hour" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>80</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext>km/hr</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: The rate of change of liters of fuel used with respect to the speed is greater when driving at <math alttext="50 kilometers per hour" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext>km/hr</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> than when driving at <math alttext="80 kilometers per hour" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>80</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext>km/hr</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

topic.text: 4.1: Interpreting the Meaning of the Derivative in Context

skill.text: Skill 3.F: Explain the meaning of mathematical solutions in context.
